sentence.text: The younger brother (Fig. 1G) was similarly affected but with a milder phenotype attributed to the progressive nature of the disease as stated by the mother.
He had exaggerated lumbar lordosis and genu recurvatum.

At the age of 6 years and 3 months, he had a height of 142 cm (+5.1 SD), a head circumference of 50.4 cm (âˆ’1.0 SD), arm span of 137.5 cm with normal upper/lower segment ratio (0.95 = 69/73), and excessive length of both upper and lower limbs measurements (>2.0 SD).
Orodental evaluation showed high arched palate and long uvula.
He had abnormal pronunciation of some letters, hearing impairment on audiometry, and a normal IQ score of 98 (by Stanford Binet).
Skeletal survey showed knock knees, kyphoscoliosis of lower thoracic vertebrae (Fig. 1H), arachnodactyly with no carpal or tarsal fusions, and wormian skull bones.
He had squint of the left eye and no cataract or sublaxation of lenses.
